content: Can you see stars during daytime from the bottom of a well or tall chimney?

Yes, it is possible to see stars during the daytime from the bottom of a well or a tall chimney. This phenomenon occurs due to the way light travels and is blocked in these structures.

During the day, the sky appears bright because of the scattering of sunlight by the Earth's atmosphere. This scattering makes the entire sky appear blue and overwhelms the much fainter light from stars, making them invisible to the naked eye.

However, in the bottom of a well or a tall chimney, the direct sunlight is blocked by the walls of the well or chimney. This reduces the amount of scattered light in the field of view, making the sky appear darker in that direction. As a result, some of the brighter stars may become visible even during the daytime.

This effect is similar to why you can sometimes see stars from the bottom of a deep mine shaft or from inside a cave with a small opening to the sky. The reduced ambient light allows fainter objects like stars to become visible.

It's important to note that this works best with very deep wells or chimneys that effectively block out most of the indirect daylight. Additionally, the stars that are visible will depend on their brightness and their position in the sky relative to the opening of the well or chimney.
